abstracts.cdata!:
The report assesses the outcome of three
            projects in Bulgaria with mixed results, for while the
            Critical Imports Rehabilitation Loan (CIRL), and the
            Financial and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Loan (FESAL) are
            rated satisfactory, with a likely sustainability, the
            Rehabilitation Loan (RL) is rated unsatisfactory, and
            sustainability is unlikely. The key lessons address
            primarily, the credibility issue during a critical period,
            when although actions were taken in 1996 to reverse the
            economic decline, and arrest the financial crisis,
            incomplete efforts led to the fall of the government. The
            interim government however, took immediate actions towards
            economic stabilization, and structural adjustment reform
            programs, setting the Currency Board, which established the
            credibility in Government's policies. The effective
            coordination among the international financial institutions,
            and development partners contributed to successful reform
            programs. However, the report reinforces the notion that one
            tranche, quick disbursement operations, are appropriate only
            if, agreed multi-year programs are in place, to be supported
            by a series of lending operations, and, if uncertainty
            significantly affects institutional strength, thus requiring
            continued re-calibration of project design, implementation,
            and performance.
